page.title: 03THE TWO PARISH CHURCHES
page.content: The present parish church at{Aston {Ingham}dates from Norman times and is probably built on the site of a much older church. The only remaining Norman structures are the west wall aand the chancel arch, but although the church was virtually rebuilt in 1890 many of the old features were retained. The{lead font}is one of only 38 in the country. The first church at{Cliffords {Mesne}was built in 1860 and served as both church and school.A separate church was built in 1882. There is no record of there being an older church. Regrettably both parishes are now in the position of not having a resident incumbent. Cliffords Mesne is joined with Gorsley and Newent,whilst Aston Ingham is part of a United Benefice with Linton and Upton Bishop.
